Onderwerp: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth

Thanks for your thoughts, Paige.
 
I'm afraid that I have to disagree about the virtues of a transliterating keyboard driver:  It is not optional, it is essential!  Even if you say that you are able to type "fairly quickly" in Jerome, I doubt you could do it well enough to be hired as an administrative assistant for a Read Alphabet-based office!  I'm thinking like a good 40-55 words per minute; This isn't attainable, because too many keys are on capitals. Forget the word "transliterating." The keyboard driver is simply the way keyboard must work in any language. Consider the fact that with upper case, we use 52 letters in English on 26 keys- our keyboard drivers interpret SHIFT + (letter) as a signal to put down a completely different symbol.  And in the many countries of the world, where there are far more characters than keys, E.g., China, Japan, Thailand, India, etc., several keystrokes are used to create a single complete character. This is always the case in Chinese and Japanese, where the elements of the radical characters are specified by single keystrokes, and drivers recognize combinations to create radical and more complex characters. Some of those languages, like Thai and Hindi, can present a trucated form of the writing (for example, omitting vowels, which are integrated into the shape of the complete character) by using simple keystrokes, but the full script must use multiple keys to create complete characters with the loops and flourishes which indicate vowels.  Semitic languages, like Hebrew and Arabic are a bit better off, since they normally are written without vowels, but the inclusion of the vowel of course, requires another letter keystroke.  Nearly half of the world's population uses non-Roman-based writing systems.  You can bet that if they're not hitting alt, shift, control all the time, they're hitting other combinations of characters a lot to flesh out the writing.  Even many European languages had to use backspace + (accent) on the typewriter to get all of their letters to appear correctly, since some Slavic languages can put an accent over almost every character.
 
No, its accent and then the letter. The accent keys are a little different from the normal letters. They do produce a character on the paper, but the paper doesn't move forward,
 
The computer keyboard eliminates some of that awkwardness, you can keep going forward, and the keyboard can recognize a letter combination a signifying an accented letter. Esperantists usually use an x or an h to signify the accent, with h being the easier combination to type.
Being an Esperantist myself, the creator (Zamenhof) originally said that the h should be used when there is no circumflex available. Computer users have also invented the x for this purpose. It has two advantages over the h. One; the alphabetical order is maintained, circumflexed letters always follow the uncircumflexed one, and Two; it will not lead to confusing situations where there is an uncircumflexed letter that needs to be followed by an h, as in the word flughaveno (airport). In the driver this may be a very good idea. If we'd use a non-normal character to change the value of the sound. Instead of th we'd type tx or t'. If you'd still want the ' key you'd type it twice. The French keyboard works more or less like this.
Or consider it this way: Stop thinking of the capital letters as "places" on the keyboard, and think about the actions that are required to produce a letter.  With only 26 letter keys, multiple keystrokes are going to be needed to produce most of the characters in a 62-character alphabet.  We're using the "Shift +" combination to do almost everything, when a simpler solution, not requiring the poor lil' ol pinky to do that work would be to simply type a logical character combination. 
 
Re Dvorak:  I'm the only person I know who actually tried it, and that was twice, as a matter of fact.  The second time was last year, and I converted my Windows systems both at home and work to the Dvorak schema.  I liked the more logical arrangement of the keys, and I definitely did get up to "fairly quick" typing with it, in the neighborhood of 30 words per minute.  But I abandoned it after about six months because I couldn't break that barrier, and on Qwerty, I can do 55 wpm easily.  I figured 6 months was adequate time for a trial! Dvorak has its own illogical parts too, like R and L being under the weakest fingers, and A being under a weak finger while U gets the prime real estate.  After my two shots at it, I think that in a non-Qwerty-biased world, it would be a superior alternative for someone who is just learning to type or one who has never achieved good speed with Qwerty.
 
>No one thinks of a "they" or "thaw" as "dh", and I feel it adds a needless level of complexity. 
 
Since in Senior QS we have the blessing(?) of THREE "th's" Thoth, Thither, and Other (T, H, K),  I think the easily remembered digraphs of th, dh, and xdh
Perhaps we can just ignore Thither. Other will do the job nicely.
would greatly simplify matters.  It seems a lot more sensible to me than Shift+T, Shift+H, and Shift +K, which we have now. It would be a slight exaggeration to say that I think in terms of  "dh" sounds, but as soon as one begins learning the sounds of the language, th and dh is a fairly common way of differentiating between the Thoth and Thither sounds in Roman letters. And the less unnecessary use of the Shift key, the faster and easier it goes for everyone. Another possible benefit of the transliterating driver would be that we could put the slash back where it belongs, and have the driver intelligently print a namer dot when it encounters a initial capital letter.  Thus, we could actually write things like and/or again without having to remember where the slash went, and the Shift key goes back to it's reasons for living--indicating capitals and punctuation, not letters.  Let letters and letter-combinations create letters, and Shift do punctuation selection, not letter selection.
 
That way, NO Read characters would have to be mapped onto punctuation keys, capitalization comes from natural use of the Shift key, and no punctuation marks are eliminated or even moved. 
 
Shush, Zhivago, Thoth, Thither and Church can be typed very naturally as sh, zh, th, dh, ch, which should be significantly easier to remember, and much easier to type than Cap S, Cap Z, Cap T, Cap H, small c!  They all occur in English except for dh, which once learned, won't be confused for anything else, and is quite intuitive.  Th is to dh, as t is to d, as tall is to deep, as unvoiced is to voiced. Inkling is usually represented in Roman by ng, which will do nicely.  The alternate forms, Noon, Up, and Other, could be designated by an x, which would be impossible to confuse in Shavian letters with any other meaning. Thus, xn, xa, xdh, or something similar. Again, easily remembered, x signifying "alternative form." The half-letters could be flagged by something else: say an initial h, which would give hw, hwh, hd, hz, ht, hp, hy, hh. Easily remembed: The half-letters are flagged by an initial h, for "half".
 
Although it is very tempting and easy to use ch, sh, and ng, c, x, and q will do just as nice, being unused and occuring quite often. But it's very easy to create multiple drivers, so you can always be offered a choice.
 
For more information visit www.tavultesoft.com about the programs. The newest version is a commercial one, with no built-in option to create your own drivers. Personally I'd go for the Win 3.11 alternative, which is free and does include a driver-creation option and manual. I do not know if the Win 3.11 version runs properly on Win '95+, but the driver files may still be compatible.
Finally, I heartily agree that the keyboard mapping can be improved.  It shouldn't be too difficult for me to create something a little more logical.  And I COMPLETELY agree that Read characters shouldn't be displacing punctuation symbols, no matter how infrequently used.  The problem is simple: 62 characters vs. an overwhelmed 26 letter keys.  As long as one is stuck with a mapping paradigm, the more letters, the more illogical placements (I really didn't WANT to put Other on Cap K!)
 
First, one of us should create a driver for Junior Quickscript. From this we can learn and experiment. Then automatic conversion to short forms can be added. And we can create a Shavian driver too.
 
Ewout
